Description: Pottery oil-lamp with a wheel-made open body, a central tube, a thickened rim and a short rounded nozzle, decorated with impressed circles, with traces of burning. Lip just below the rim. Pale red-brown fabric with common white inclusions and some mica. Right part reconstructed from plaster. Seems to have 'l' incised shallowly below nozzle.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Archaic Greek wheel-made lamp from East Greece. Parallels from Athens (Howland 1958, see types 9 and 11). Parallels from Rhodes (one from a grave, another from domestic structure), Megara Hyblaea and Chios, from contexts dated to between 625BC and 570BC, though Bailey dates this form to 600BC-575BC (Bailey 1975, 94, Q147). Parallels in the British Museum from Ephesus (British Museum GR 1971,1224.9) and parallels from Naukratis (British Museum GR 1886,0401.1336; Boston MFA 86.899; 88.906; Fitzwilliam, Cambridge GR.57.1899; Bristol Museum H846). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.04) (Phase 3)
